Armonk, NY, USA). Normally distributed continuous data were presented as the 40 mean± standard deviation; non-normally distributed data were presented as the 41 median (interquartile range). Classification data were presented as number (%).

Categorical variables were analyzed using the χ 2 test or Fisher's exact test. Normally 43 distributed continuous data were analyzed using the two-sample t test. 44 5 1 Results 2 Patient Demographics 3 A total of 421 patients with COVID-19 were admitted to the mobile hospital from 4

February 9th to March 5th, 2020 and were included in the present study. Of these 5 patients, 49.2% were female. The median patient age 52 (39-61) years, 13.3% were 6 older than 65 years, and 99.5% were living in Wuhan. The percentage of patients with 7 a history of contact with patients with COVID-19 was 51.3%, while 20.2% had a 8 history of contact with patients with fever. The most common presenting symptom 9 was fever, which was present in 255 patients (60.6%) on admission, followed by 10 cough (219 patients; 52.0%). Among the 421 patients, 5.2% showed no obvious 11 symptoms. Comorbid conditions were present in 20.9% of all patients.

Of the patients who were discharged from the cabin hospital, 362 (86.0%) were 13 categorized as recovered, while 59 (14.0%) were categorized as severe and were 14 transferred to designated hospitals. The patients in severe cases were older than those 15 in recovered cases by a median of 5 years. High fever (>39.0℃), dyspnoea, and 16 diarrhea were more common in severe cases than in recovered cases (18.6% versus 17 6.6%, P=0.002; 45.8% versus 3.9%, P<.0001; 15.3% versus 0.6%, P<.0001).

FIGREF0.text: Question：Whether a mobile cabin hospital can provide a safe treatment 7 site for patients with mild COVID-19 symptoms remains unknown. 8 Study Design and Methods: We retrospectively reviewed the medical records of 421 9 patients with COVID-19 admitted to a mobile cabin hospital in Wuhan from February 10 9th to March 5th, 2020. Clinical data comprised patient age, sex, clinical presentation, 11 chest imaging, nucleic acid testing, length of hospitalization, and outcomes.

FIGREF1.text: The outcome was recovery and hospital discharge in 86% of patients, while 13 14.0% developed severe symptoms and were transferred to a designated hospital. The 14 most common presenting symptoms were fever (60.6%) and cough (52.0%), while15 5.2% showed no obvious symptoms. High fever (>39.0 ) was more common in ℃ 16 severe cases than recovered cases (18.6% versus 6.6%). The distribution of lung 17 lesions was peripheral in 85.0% of patients, multifocal in 69.4%, and bilateral in 18 68.2%. The most common pattern was ground-glass opacity (67.7%), followed by 19 patchy shadowing (49.2%). The incidence of patchy shadowing was higher in severe 20 patients (66.1%) than in those who recovered (31.8%, P<.0001). The median length of 21 hospitalization was 17 (14-19) days, and the median time taken for positive real-time 22 reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction results to become negative in 23 recovered patients was 8 (6-10) days.

FIGREF2.text: Medical staff in the mobile hospital provided entertainment activities with Chinese 6 characteristics, such as square dancing and Tai Chi, to improve the patients' physical 7 and mental conditions. The mobile hospital was equipped with a mobile CT machine, 8 oxygen cylinders, pulse oximeters, emergency room, and a mobile P3 laboratory 9 capable of performing nucleic acid tests. All patients in the mobile hospital received 10 mainly oral medications.11 12 Nucleic Acid Assay and Chest CT 13 Throat swab samples were collected for the extraction of COVID-19 RNA from 14 patients with suspected COVID-19. Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain 15 reaction (RT-PCR) assays were performed in accordance with the protocol established 16 by the WHO. 9 For patients with multiple RT-PCR assays, repeated testing was 17 performed at least 24 hours after the initial test. All images were obtained using one 18 of two CT systems (uCT 528, United Imaging, China; ScientCare CT 16, MinFound, 19 China) with the patients in the supine position. All images were reviewed and graded 20 by a chest radiologist and a respiratory physician with more than 10 years of 21 experience each (C.S.X., W.W.). All chest CT images were analyzed independently 22 and final decisions reached by consensus. CT was performed on admission to the 23 mobile hospital and when a patient's condition changed during hospitalization. The lower lung lobes 24 were more susceptible to infection lesions than the upper lobes. FIGREF4.text: Based on the demand for medical management, large indoor stadiums and convention 20 centers were reconstructed as mobile cabin hospitals with a capacity of more than21 20,000 beds for patients with COVID-19 with mild symptoms. The establishment of 22 mobile hospitals not only relieves the shortage of medical resources, but also 23 promotes the mental health of medical staff and the public. 14,15 24

Most of these comorbidities were 32 effectively controlled by the administration of oral medications in the mobile cabin 33 hospital. 34 Chest CT revealed no abnormalities in 24 of the 421 patients (5.7%). Among the 35 patients with abnormal findings on chest CT, there was no predilection for the number 36 of affected lung lobes. However, the right lower lobe was most commonly affected of 37 all the lung lobes. This might be caused by the anatomical structure of the trachea and 38bronchi; as the right bronchus is short and straight, SARS-CoV-2 might be more 39 likely to affect this location. 17 Lower respiratory tract symptoms were more common 40 than upper respiratory tract symptoms, indicating that the cells targeted by the virus 41 might be located in the lower lobes.18  We speculate that the higher incidence of 42 lesions in the lower airways seen in the present study may be related to false negative 43 results obtained from throat swab samples, as reported in a recent study. was another characteristic of the present patients, similar to the 6 findings of a previous clinical study.21    7
